title: 105_s1888
content: The Act may be cited as the "Internet Fairness and Interstate Responsibility Act" or "Net FAIR Act". Congress finds that it can best regulate and tax Internet activity to ensure consistency and fairness. A common lexicon for Internet terms is essential for government interactions. Some states have already implemented unique taxes on Internet commerce. The Internet's unique global nature allows for cross-border communication and commerce, presenting challenges with over 30,000 taxing jurisdictions in the US. This creates a variety of taxes and rates on Internet activity, impacting entrepreneurs and small businesses looking to reach global markets. The US must set an example for regulating and taxing Internet activity to ensure consistency and fairness. The United States should set an example by preventing discriminatory taxation on Internet activities to encourage global partners to avoid taxing such activities. Innovation in computer technology, which has flourished in a tax-free environment, should be protected from local, State, and Federal taxation to allow the Internet to reach its full potential. The President should pursue agreements through international organizations to support this initiative. The United States should lead by example in preventing discriminatory taxation on Internet activities to promote global partners' avoidance of taxing such transactions. The President should work with international organizations to ensure that commercial transactions on the Internet are free from tariffs and discriminatory taxation. Moratorium on imposition of taxes on internet and internet-related computer services. Moratorium on state and local taxes on the Internet and Internet-related services, with exceptions for taxes on net income, business license taxes, and sales or use taxes. The moratorium prohibits state and local taxes on Internet and Internet-related services, except for certain taxes like net income, business license taxes, and sales or use taxes on transactions conducted through the Internet. The moratorium on state and local taxes for Internet and Internet-related services will end on December 31, 2001. The moratorium on state and local taxes for Internet and Internet-related services will end on December 31, 2001. SEC. 4. COMMISSION ON INTERNET TAXATION AND REGULATION. Establishment of the Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation with 15 members including Secretaries of Commerce, State, and Treasury, as well as 12 members appointed by the President without political affiliation. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation consists of 15 members, including CEOs of political subdivisions, individuals from computer and software companies, and individuals from electronic commerce companies. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation consists of 15 members appointed for life, with a Chairman and Vice Chairman selected from among its members. The Commission meets at the Chairman's call, with a majority forming a quorum for meetings and hearings. Its duties include conducting a thorough study of taxation. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation is tasked with studying taxation and regulation of the Internet and Internet-related services under State and local law, identifying inconsistencies, considering the impact of Federal statutes and regulations, and proposing model legislation for commercial transactions on the Internet to ensure uniform treatment under Federal and State law. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation is responsible for proposing model legislation for commercial transactions on the Internet, defining covered activities, and establishing regulatory structures. The Commission must have at least 10 members approve any position taken under this subsection. A report on its activities must be submitted to Congress and the President by December 31, 2000. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation will submit a report to Congress and the President detailing its findings, recommendations, proposed model legislation, and any additional findings and recommendations deemed appropriate. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill its objectives. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation has the authority to gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Commission members not employed by the government will receive compensation. The Commission on Internet Taxation and Regulation members shall be compensated at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. Officers or employees of the US government will serve without additional compensation. Members will also receive travel expenses as authorized for agency employees. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman can also procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Internet" refers to the interconnected network of computer networks using TCP/IP to transmit information. "Internet-related services" include Internet access services and online services. The term "tax" includes any tax, license, or fee imposed by a governmental entity, including the obligation for the seller to collect and remit taxes imposed on the buyer.
